skill.name: logprob-prefill-analysis
skill.description: Reproduces the full prefill sensitivity analysis pipeline for reward hacking indicators. Use when evaluating how susceptible model checkpoints are to exploit-eliciting prefills, computing token-based trajectories, or comparing logprob vs token-count as predictors of exploitability.
skill.summary: Reproduces the full prefill sensitivity analysis pipeline for reward hacking indicators. Use when ev...
skill.author: EleutherAI

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only SKILL.md markdown file. No executable code, network calls, filesystem access, or environment variable reads. The skill describes a research pipeline for AI safety researchers analyzing model behavior.

content.user_title: Analyze model susceptibility to reward hacking
content.value_statement: This skill provides documentation for running prefill sensitivity analysis to measure how easily AI models can be manipulated into generating exploit code. Researchers use it to compare token-count versus logprob metrics for predicting reward hacking susceptibility across model checkpoints.
actual_capabilities: Documents prefill sensitivity evaluation pipeline for measuring model exploitability
Explains token-based trajectory analysis for tracking exploit accessibility over training
Describes logprob computation for measuring how natural exploit reasoning appears to models
Provides integrated analysis comparing token-count versus logprob predictors
Covers experiment context logging for reproducible research runs
Includes troubleshooting guidance for CUDA memory and vLLM server issues
limitations: Documentation-only skill - users must run Python scripts described in the documentation
Requires pre-existing model checkpoints and vLLM installation to execute analyses
Does not perform analysis itself - provides commands and configuration guidance
Skill assumes access to SFT checkpoints and prefill source data

use_cases.title: Measure Model Vulnerability
use_cases.description: Evaluate how susceptible trained models are to reward hacking by measuring prefill token thresholds and logprob scores across checkpoints

use_cases.title: Track Training Progression
use_cases.description: Analyze how exploit accessibility changes during SFT training to identify when models become vulnerable

use_cases.title: Compare Prediction Metrics
use_cases.description: Compare RÂ² values between token-based and logprob-based metrics for predicting when models become exploitable

prompt_templates.title: Run Full Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I run the full prefill sensitivity analysis pipeline using the run_full_prefill_analysis.py script?

prompt_templates.title: Analyze Trajectories
prompt_templates.prompt: What commands do I use to analyze token-based trajectories and compute minimum prefill tokens needed for exploits?

prompt_templates.title: Compute Logprobs
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to compute prefill logprobs for a model checkpoint and batch process multiple checkpoints.

prompt_templates.title: Compare Metrics
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I merge token-based and logprob-based metrics to compare their predictive power using integrate_logprob_trajectory.py?

output_examples.input: How do I run the full prefill sensitivity analysis pipeline?
output: The orchestration script automatically discovers checkpoints from config.yaml
Add --dry-run flag to preview execution without running
Add --skip-logprob to run trajectory analysis only
Results are saved to timestamped directories with full experiment context

best_practices: Use experiment context logging (--use-run-context flag) to capture reproducibility metadata including Git commit, Python version, and environment details
Start with --dry-run to verify configuration before executing long-running analysis pipelines
Use the threshold parameter (default 10) to define when a model is considered easily exploitable based on min_prefill tokens
anti_patterns: Running full analysis without first verifying checkpoint availability in config.yaml
Ignoring the distinction between word tokens and subword tokens when interpreting results
Using mean logprob instead of sum logprob when comparing across different prefill lengths

faq.question: What models and frameworks does this analysis support?
faq.answer: Works with SFT checkpoints served via vLLM. gpt-oss models use Harmony format with thinking field auto-detection.

faq.question: What compute resources are required?
faq.answer: GPU recommended for logprob computation. CUDA OOM can be addressed with --max-samples 50 or --dtype float16.

faq.question: How long does full analysis take?
faq.answer: Depends on checkpoint count and prefill levels. The orchestration script processes all checkpoints automatically.

faq.question: Is data saved securely?
faq.answer: Results written to local results/ directory. No external data transmission occurs during analysis execution.

faq.question: What if vLLM server fails to start?
faq.answer: Ensure server fully starts before evaluation. Check logs for Uvicorn running message. Use pkill to clean up stuck processes.

faq.question: How does this differ from standard model evaluation?
faq.answer: Tracks exploit accessibility over training progression, comparing how easily models can be manipulated via prefill tokens.
